content.html:
I‚Äôve always liked the idea that your website can be your API. Like, you‚Äôve already got URLs to identify resources, so why not make that URL structure predictable and those resources parsable?

That‚Äôs why the (read-only) API for The Session doesn‚Äôt live at a separate subdomain. It uses the same URL structure as the regular site, but you can request the resources in an alternative format: JSON, XML, RSS.

This works out pretty well, mostly because I put a lot of thought into the URL structure of the site. I‚Äôm something of a URL fetishist, but I think that taking a URL-first approach to information architecture can be a good exercise.

Most of the resources on The Session involve nouns like tunes, events, discussions, and so on. There‚Äôs a consistent and predictable structure to the URLs for those sections:

  • /things
  • /things/new
  • /things/search

And then an idividual item can be found at:

  • things/ID

That‚Äôs all nice and predictable and the naming of the URLs matches what you‚Äôd expect to find:

  • tunes
  • tunes/new
  • tunes/search?q=Ireland
  • tunes/320

Tunes, events, discussions, sessions. Those are all fine. But there‚Äôs one section of the site that has this root URL:

/recordings

When I was coming up with the URL structure twenty years ago, it was clear what you‚Äôd find there: track listings for albums of music. No one would‚Äôve expected to find actual recordings of music available to listen to on-demand. The bandwidth constraints and technical limitations of the time made that clear.

Two decades on, the situation has changed. Now someone new to the site might well expect to hit a link called ‚Äúrecordings‚Äù and expect to hear actual recordings of music.

So I should probably change the label on the link. I don‚Äôt think ‚Äúalbums‚Äù is quite right‚Äîwhat even is an album any more? The word ‚Äúdiscography‚Äù is probably the most appropriate label.

Here‚Äôs my dilemma: if I update the label, should I also update the URL structure?

Right now, the section of the site with /tunes URLs is labelled ‚Äútunes‚Äù. The section of the site with /events URLs is labelled ‚Äúevents‚Äù. Currently the section of the site with /recordings URLs is labelled ‚Äúrecordings‚Äù, but may soon be labelled ‚Äúdiscography‚Äù.

If you click on ‚Äútunes‚Äù, you end up at /tunes. But if you click on ‚Äúdiscography‚Äù, you end up at /recordings.

Is that okay? Am I the only one that would be bothered by that?

I could update the URLs to match the labelling (with redirects for the old URLs, of course), but I‚Äôm not so keen on this URL structure:

  • /discography
  • /discography/new
  • /discography/search
  • /discography/ID

It doesn‚Äôt seem as tidy as:

  • /recordings
  • /recordings/new
  • /recordings/search
  • /recordings/ID

But if I don‚Äôt update the URLs to match the label, then I‚Äôm just going to have to live with the mismatch.

I‚Äôm just thinking out loud here. I think I should definitely update the label. I just won‚Äôt make any decision on changing URLs for a while yet.

content.html:
Transient Frameworks ¬∑ Matthias Ott ‚Äì User Experience Designer

Frameworks come and go. They are transient. Web standards, on the other hand, are the reason the Web is good now and it will become even better in the future.

content.html:
Simon Collison | Farewell, Twitter

I‚Äôve been feeling exactly what Colly articulates here:

I‚Äôm aware that smart friends still tweet passing thoughts without a care, and I can‚Äôt understand why. Some seem happy to repost damning articles about the situation and then carry on tweeting without a care.

content.html:
A few weeks back, a friend likened something I said to what Elon Musk would say.

They retracted, but with each of Musk‚Äôs unhinged proclamations, the insult grows like a virus.

I‚Äôm honestly not sure our friendship can get past it.

content.html:
At the end of next week, I will sally forth to California. I‚Äôm going to wend my way to San Francisco where I will be speaking at An Event Apart.

I am very much looking forward to speaking at my first in-person AEAs in exactly three years. That was also in San Francisco, right before The Situation.

I hope to see you there. There are still tickets available.

I‚Äôve put together a brand new talk that I‚Äôm very excited about. I‚Äôve already written about the prep for this talk:

So while I‚Äôve been feeling somewhat under the gun as I‚Äôve been preparing this new talk for An Event Apart, I‚Äôve also been feeling that the talk is just the culmination; a way of tying together some stuff I‚Äôve been writing about it here for the past year or two.

The talk is called Declarative Design. Here‚Äôs the blurb:

Different browsers, different devices, different network speeds‚Ä¶designing for the web can feel like a never-ending battle for control. But what if the solution is to relinquish control? Instead of battling the unknowns, we can lean into them. In the world of programming, there‚Äôs the idea of declarative languages: describing what you want to achieve without specifying the exact steps to get there. In this talk, we‚Äôll take this concept of declarative programming and apply it to designing for the web. Instead of focusing on controlling the outputs of the design process, we‚Äôll look at creating the right inputs instead. Leave the final calculations for the outputs to the browser‚Äîthat‚Äôs what computers are good at. We‚Äôll look at CSS features, design systems, design principles, and more. Then you‚Äôll be ready to embrace the fluid, ever-changing, glorious messiness of the World Wide Web!

If you‚Äôd a glimpse into the inside of my head while I‚Äôve been preparing this talk, here‚Äôs a linkdump of various resources that are either mentioned in the talk or influenced it‚Ä¶

Declarative Design

  • Declarative design on adactio.com
  • Utopia by James Gilyead and Trys Mudford
  • Every Layout by Heydon Pickering and Andy Bell
  • Be the browser‚Äôs mentor, not its micromanager by Andy Bell
  • Layout Land by Jen Simmons
  • Designing Intrinsic Layouts by Jen Simmons on adactio.com

HTML

  • A declarative Web Share API on adactio.com
  • A polyfill for button type=‚Äùshare‚Äù on adactio.com
  • The reason for a share button type on adactio.com
  • Share Button Type explainer on Github
  • When should there be a declarative version of a JavaScript API? on adactio.com
  • How to (not) make a button by Tomas Pustelnik

CSS

  • The CSS Mindset by Max B√∂ck
  • Contextual Spacing For Intrinsic Web Design by Stephanie Eckles
  • The CSS mental model by Peter Paul Koch
  • CSS Forces by Tim Brown

Design Tools

  • Our web design tools are holding us¬†back by Vasilis van Gemert
  • Traditional Web Design Process is Fundamentally Broken by Jason Grigsby
  • Web Design Tool Wish List by Jason Grigsby
  • Declarative Design Tools (archived) by Jem Gold

Design systems

  • Declarative design systems on adactio.com
  • Design systems thinking on adactio.com

History

  • Cascading HTML style sheets ‚Äî a proposal by H√•kon Wium Lie, 1994
  • A Dao of Web Design by John Allsopp, 2000
  • Responsive Web Design by Ethan Marcotte, 2010

People

  • Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
  • Miles Davis
  • Tim Berners-Lee

content.html:
I am very excited to announce that UX London will be back in 2023!

We‚Äôre returning to Tobacco Dock. Save the dates: June 22nd and 23rd.

Wait ‚Ä¶that‚Äôs only two days. Previously UX London was a three-day event and you could either go for all three days or get a ticket for just one day.

Well, that‚Äôs changing. UX London 2023 will be condensed into a two-day event. You get a ticket for both days and everyone shares the experience.

I‚Äôm very excited about this! I‚Äôm planning to make some other tweaks to the format, but the basic structure of each day remains roughly the same: inspirational talks in the morning followed by hands-on workshops in the afternoon.

As for the who‚Äôll be giving those talks and running those workshops ‚Ä¶well, that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm currently putting together. For the second year in row, I‚Äôm curating the line-up. It‚Äôs exciting‚Äîlike a planning a heist, assembling a team of supersmart people with specialised skillsets.

I can‚Äôt wait to reveal more. For now though, you can trust me when I say that the line-up is going to be stellar.

If you do trust me, you can get your super early-bird ticket, you‚Äôve got until this Friday, December 2nd.

The super early-bird tickets are an absolute steal at ¬£695 plus VAT. After Friday, you‚Äôll be able to get early-bird tickets for the more reasonable price of ¬£995 plus VAT.

Keep an eye on the UX London website for speaker announcements. I‚Äôll also be revealing those updates here too because, as you can probably tell, I‚Äôm positively gleeful about UX London 2023.

See you there!

content.html:
Designing a Utopian layout grid: Working with fluid responsive values in a static design tool. | Utopia

James describes his process for designing fluid grid layouts, which very much involves working with the grain of the web but against the grain of our design tools:

In 2022 our design tools are still based around fixed-size artboards, while we‚Äôre trying to design products which scale gracefully to suit any screen.
content.value:
Designing a Utopian layout grid: Working with fluid responsive values in a static design tool. | Utopia



James describes his process for designing fluid grid layouts, which very much involves working with the grain of the web but against the grain of our design tools:


  In 2022 our design tools are still based around fixed-size artboards, while we‚Äôre trying to design products which scale gracefully to suit any screen.

name: Designing a Utopian layout grid: Working with fluid responsive values in a static design tool. | Utopia

content.html:
jwz: PSA: Do Not Use Services That Hate The Internet

If you‚Äôre thinking of signing up to Hive or Post:

If posts in a social media app do not have URLs that can be linked to and viewed in an unauthenticated browser, or if there is no way to make a new post from a browser, then that program is not a part of the World Wide Web in any meaningful way.

Consign that app to oblivion.

content.html:
Mastodon is a gateway | Andy Bell

I‚Äôve been very guilty of putting all my eggs in the Twitter basket over the last couple of years, especially, and all of that has been destroyed by one bellend billionaire. I‚Äôm determined not to make that mistake again and even more determined to make my little home on the internet‚Äîthis website‚Äîas lovely and sustainable as I can make it.

content.html:
How to Weave the Artisan Web | Whatever

Wouldn‚Äôt it be nice to have a site that‚Äôs not run by an amoral billionaire chaos engine, or algorithmically designed to keep you doomscrolling in a state of fear and anger, or is essentially spyware for governments and/or corporations? Wouldn‚Äôt it be nice not to have ads shoved in your face every time you open an app to see what your friends are up to? Wouldn‚Äôt it be nice to know that when your friends post something, you‚Äôll actually see it without a social media platform deciding whether to shove it down your feed and pump that feed full of stuff you didn‚Äôt ask for?

Wouldn‚Äôt that be great?
